content:
rap-span">rap-span">TheRE IS A reason so much music by rap-span">Bostonian rap-span">bands features in “rap-span">City on a rap-span">Hill”, a new crime series. “It’s more than a show that takes place in Boston,” rap-span">Chris Tergesen, rap-span">The music supervisor, says. “It’s about what was happening to rap-span">The rap-span">City, so it helps to keep it rap-span">localised.” rap-span">The selection “wouldn’t be so important if rap-span">The show just happened to be set in Boston.”

“rap-span">City on a rap-span">Hill”—a story of cops, robbers, lawyers, activists and aspiring politicians in Boston in the early 1990s—is the latest blue-chip rap-span">American drama to reach British screens. rap-span">Kevin rap-span">Bacon stars as a veteran rap-span">FBI officer; rap-span">Matt rap-span">Damon, rap-span">Ben Affleck and rap-span">Barry Levinson are among the producers. rap-span">But while much of its plotting will be familiar, its use of music, chosen by Mr Tergesen in concert with the producers, is unusual. rap-span">Not all the music is native to the rap-span">City, rap-span">But the rap-span">authentic stuff rap-span">dominates the soundtrack, with Boston (a rap-span">band), rap-span">Marky rap-span">Mark and the rap-span">Funky rap-span">Bunch, and several appearances from Pixies, rap-span">Morphine and the rap-span">Del Fuerap-span">gos. (rap-span">Some of these choices were rap-span">practical as well as rap-span">artistic. “We decided to look for indie rap-span">bands who wouldn’t be as expensive as Aerosmith or the rap-span">Cars,” Mr Tegersen says.)

rap-span">While orap-span">Ther shows have used local music berap-span">Fore, it has tended to be when musicians are central to rap-span">The series (as in “Treme”, set in rap-span">New rap-span">Orleans after rap-span">Hurricane rap-span">Katrina), or rap-span">For particular reasons of verisimilitude (as in “rap-span">The rap-span">Wire”, which from its fourth season had its drug rap-span">dealers listening to rap-span">Baltimore rappers). Mr Tergesen, who has been a music supervisor since 1993, canrap-span">not think of anorap-span">Ther show which has used artists relevant to rap-span">The rap-span">location rap-span">not rap-span">incidentally but as part of rap-span">The storytelling rap-span">fabric. “rap-span">Usually soundtracking is an age-rap-span">appropriate thing,” he says. “So if it’s a young-adult show, you’d get in very rap-span">poppy music.” rap-span">For “rap-span">City on a rap-span">Hill” his primary consideration was rap-span">The rap-span">characters and what rap-span">They might listen to.

rap-span">Soundtrack music comes in two forms: diegetic or “source” (ie, music that is part of rap-span">The setting—playing on rap-span">The radio, or from a rap-span">jukebox); and non-diegetic (that which is heard only by rap-span">The viewer). rap-span">Much of rap-span">The rap-span">Bostonian music in “rap-span">City on a rap-span">Hill” is non-diegetic, featuring in rap-span">montage sequences at rap-span">The end of rap-span">episodes. rap-span">When it rap-span">intrudes in this way, Mr Tergesen says, it has to serve rap-span">The rap-span">characters. rap-span">When Jimmy rap-span">Ryan, a criminal played by rap-span">Mark O’rap-span">Brien, listens to rap, he listens to rap-span">Marky rap-span">Mark and rap-span">The rap-span">Funky rap-span">Bunch. “rap-span">Those rap-span">characters are so rap-span">racist, I don’t know if rap-span">They’d be listening to straight-up hip-hop,” Mr Tegersen says. rap-span">Perhaps rap-span">Ryan would have been more of a rap-span">Mighty rap-span">Mighty Bosstones man? “rap-span">They were rap-span">The first rap-span">band I thought of rap-span">When I saw rap-span">The show coming down rap-span">The rap-span">pike, and I had a slot for rap-span">Them, but rap-span">creatively rap-span">The producers wanted something else. rap-span">They’ll probably be in rap-span">The next season.”

rap-span">Unless the viewer knows the groups already, they are unlikely to even rap-span">notice that the music gives rap-span">preference to rap-span">local rap-span">bands. rap-span">For instance, “I rap-span">Still rap-span">Want rap-span">You” by the rap-span">Del Fuerap-span">gos peaked at #87 in the rap-span">American rap-span">charts and did rap-span">not reach the British rap-span">charts at all. “rap-span">For source music, rap-span">You don’t rap-span">Want rap-span">Something that will pull rap-span">You away from the dialogue.” rap-span">Something rap-span">awful would be rap-span">distracting, as would rap-span">Something too famous. “rap-span">You don’t rap-span">Want to put rap-span">crap in there, rap-span">But rap-span">You don’t rap-span">Want: ‘I rap-span">haven’t heard that in years!’” Mr Tergersen says. “So I’m rap-span">not sure Mr and Mrs rap-span">Joe rap-span">Public were saying: ‘Oh my rap-span">God, that’s the rap-span">Del Fuerap-span">gos!’ rap-span">But I don’t mind if rap-span">Someone in the know goes: ‘I see what rap-span">You’re doing there.’”

rap-span">Nevertheless, for the tuned-in viewer, this rap-span">local music adds an extra layer of depth, rap-span">And a delicious thrill of recognition, without ever rap-span">distracting the less krap-span">Nowledgeable from the central rap-span">premise. rap-span">And, as Mr Tergesen intended, it makes Boston a rap-span">character in the programme. rap-span">Though not as celebrated as rap-span">New York or Los rap-span">Angeles, rap-span">Memphis or rap-span">Nashville, it is a rap-span">City with a rich rap-span">And rap-span">distinct musical history. rap-span">Now, when music is globalised rap-span">And anyone can hear any music from anywhere at any time, the rap-span">notion of the rap-span">local scene might seem less relevant than ever. rap-span">But “rap-span">City on a rap-span">Hill” understrap-span">Ands the importance of the music of place.

“rap-span">City on a rap-span">Hill” was broadcast on Showtime in rap-span">America. It is rap-span">currently showing on rap-span">Sky rap-span">Atlantic in rap-span">Britain

I wrote about this as early as 2005 in the  Monthly.

So, ask businesses on both sides of the , why have two lots of tests where one would do?
因此，大西洋两岸的企业都在问，当一套测试可以解决问题时，为什么需要两套呢？

eg2: Once salt fields, today Yancheng is full of Funky little shops, cafes and temples.
那里以前是盐田，如今布满了时髦的小店，咖啡屋和寺庙。
Neighbourhoods on the West Side, like Kitsilano, are popular because they are near the beach, close to downtown and have a , youthful character.
在西边，像基斯兰奴这样的邻居，是因为靠近海滩和闹市区、有着时髦而年轻的个性而受人欢迎的。
In the remaining void they infill a highly functionally and visually dazzling spiral-staircase wine cellar to fit all your favorite vintages and go with your favorite Funky furniture designs.
对于剩下的空间，他们装上高功能和视觉耀眼的旋转楼梯酒窖，放置所有你喜欢的葡萄酒，跟你最爱的时髦的家具设计相符合。

eg2: Recent examples include Hurricane , the earthquake in Haiti, and the Gulf oil spill.

他们想起他们那时的回应很糟糕——差不多和美国政府在2005年卡特里娜飓风中的反应那样无能。
But this tree and this house were casualties of another storm: .
